Sharing needles and handling the deceased
or sick are high risk factors
How much virus is shed in
EBOV found in a variety of bodily fluids
, one of five species of viruses in the genus
has been identified as the etiological agent of the 2014 outbreak of Ebola virus disease (EVD). In
humans, EBOV has been found in variety of bodily fluids, including saliva, blood, breast milk, stool,
routes of transmission, including direct contact, fomite,
successfully infect after oral, conjunctival, respiratory, intramuscular, intraperitoneal and submuc
tious doses of less than 10 plaque
forming units (pfu) of EBOV have been
reported to cause viremia in NHPs, depending on the route of administration
highly infectious, for a low dose of virus is suff
icient to cause disease, and EBOV is contagious; it is
shed in multiple bodily secretions and easily transmitted through contact with these fluids.
Assessing the potential routes of EBOV transmission, the United States Centers for Disease Control
ntion (CDC) has communicated the scientific consensus that EBOV spreads only through
direct contact with mucous membranes or through broken skin with infected blood or bodily fluids,
contaminated objects such as needles, and contact with infected animals
personnel are given precautions against droplet transmission.
human EBOV transmission is based mainly on epidemiological evidence
. While authors have addressed what is
many unanswered questions remain. Experiments should augment our knowledge about EBOV
transmission and improve our current retrospective understanding. Therefore, we review the present
d examine how research could answer remaining questions.
